introduction.p: Motion that fall on a straight line can be described by viewing the motion occuring on one of the Cartesian axes, say the x axis. With this choice, we denote the position, velocity, and acceleration at instant t by x , v_x , and a_x respectively. The subscript is there to remind us our choice of the axis. The magnitude of v_x gives the speed, |v_x|, at that instant.

We use a sign convention to follow the directions of velocity and acceleration. The source of these sign conventions will become clear after you learn vectors. The following diagrams clarify the sign assignments of velocity and acceleration.

p.p: The velocity v_x is positive if object is moving in the direction of positive axis and negative if in the opposite direction.
Acceleration a_x is positive in two situations: if either v_x is positive and speeding up OR v_x is negative and slowing down.
Acceleration a_x is negative in two situations: if either v_x is negative and speeding up OR v_x is positive and slowing down.

sidebyside.p:
We usually study one-dimensional kinematics for constant acceleration motion during an interval \Delta t = t_f - t_i . The change in position, \Delta x = x_f-x_i and change in velocity \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} during this interval can be shown to obey the following relations.
\amp \Delta v_x = a_x \Delta t. \amp \Delta x = v_{av,x} \Delta t,

introduction.p:
where
v_{av,x} = \dfrac{v_{i,x} + v_{f,x}}{2}.
It is possible to eliminate \Delta t from these equations to obtain
v_{f,x}^2 = v_{i,x}^2 + 2 a_x \left( \Delta x \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-t-equation . It is also possible to eliminate v_{f,x} to obtain another useful equation
\Delta x = v_{i,x} \Delta t + \dfrac{1}{2}a_x\left(\Delta t \right)^2,
which we will refer to as the no-v_f-equation.

Some special motions require simplified analysis. For instance, if velocity is constant, then, in these equations
a_x = 0\ \ \ \ (\text{constant velocity case})

Another important special situation occurs when speed is constant during a motion. Speed at an instant is equal to the absolute value of the velocity at that instant, i.e., in one-dimensional situation, you would strip the sign of the velocity to get the speed at that instant. Even though you can get speed at an instant from the velocity at that instant, the average speed during an interval is not related to the average velocity over that interval due to the way averaging is done in the two cases.

Average speed to be denoted by the symbol v_{s,av} is totality of distance covered divided by the time taken. Thus, if you move from origin to x = 10 \text{ cm} and return to origin, you would actually cover a distance of 20 \text{ cm} even though your \Delta x = 0 since your initial x is the same as your final x. We denote the actual distance covered by the letter d . In constant speed motion following equations are used.
\amp |v_f| = |v_i| = v_{s,av} \amp d = v_{s,av} \, \Delta t

statement.p: A ball is rolling in a straight track. At the end of the track, the ball hits a wall and bounces back with the same speed. Ignore the time the ball was in contact with the wall during the collision. Let the original direction of ball be the positive x axis direction. Let the ball be at x = 15\text{ cm} at t = 0 , and at x = 75\text{ cm} at t = 10\text{ sec} . The wall is at x = 100\text{ cm}. What are (a) the average velocity and (b) average speed during the t = 0 to t = 10\text{ sec} interval?

hint.p: Average velocity is based on coordinates and average speed is based on actual distance covered.

solution.p: (a) Average Velocity : For the sake of brevity, we will drop the coordinate subscript x from the symbols.

The definition of average velocity for a one-dimensional motion on x axis is
v_{av} = \dfrac{\Delta x }{\Delta t}.
Therefore,
v_{av} = \dfrac{75\text{ cm} - 15\text{ cm}}{10\text{ sec}} = 6 \text{ cm/s}.

The definition of average speed for any motion is
v_{s,av} = \dfrac{d }{\Delta t}.
The motion has two legs here: (1) from x = 15\text{ cm} to x = 100\text{ cm} (i.e., the wall) and (2) from x = 100\text{ cm} to x = 75\text{ cm} . We need to add these distances, not just difference in coordinates. Therefore,
v_{s,av} = \dfrac{85\text{ cm} + 25\text{ cm}}{10\text{ sec}} = 11 \text{ cm/s}.

exercise.title: Predicting Final Velocity in a Constant Acceleration Motion

statement.p: A skier is coming down a steep slope with a constant acceleration a = 3.0\text{ m/s}^2. If the speed of the skier at the top of the hill was 0 , what is his speed when he has skied a distance of 40 \text{ m} down the hill? Take the positive x axis to point down the hill.

hint.p: Since we don't need \Delta t the no-t-equation can be useful

solution.p:
For the sake of brevity, we will drop the coordinate subscript x from the symbols. Here taking the x axis down the hill makes all the motion along the x axis. From the problem statement, we can get the following.
a = 3.0\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ \Delta x = 40 \text{ m},\ \ v_i = 0,\ \ v_f = ?
The no-t-equation is perfect for this and gives
v_f^2 = v_i^2 + 2 a (\Delta x)^2 = 0 + 2 \times 3 \times 40^2 = 9600.
Taking square root of both sides gives two values
v_f = \pm 98\text{ m/s}.
Since the velocity we want to in the direction of the positive x axis, we want the positive root.
v_f = + 98\text{ m/s}.
We want the speed, which is the absolute value of this velocity.

statement.p: A steel ball is lauched vertically up with speed 20\text{ m/s}, i.e., an immediate instant after the ball leaves the launcher its speed is 20\text{ m/s}. How long does it take to reach the top of its trajectory? Assume the acceleration has value 9.81\text{ m/s}^2 and is pointed down.

hint.p: The velocity at the top is zero since velocity goes from being positive to being negative.

solution.p: For the sake of brevity, we will drop the coordinate subscript y from the symbols. Let us use y axis for the vertical motion with origin at the point the ball left and the direction of positive y being up. This will make a = -9.81\text{ m/s}^2.

The velocity along the path before reaching the top is positive, and after the ball starts to fall, the velocity is negative. That means, right at the top point, velocity is zero. We take t_i the instant of launch and t_f at the top. The information in the problem statement can be summarized now.
a = -9.81\text{ m/s}^2,\ \ v_i = + 20\text{ m/s},\ \ v_f = 0,\ \ \Delta t = ?
We can get \Delta t by using the acceleration equation.
\Delta v = a\, \Delta t \Longrightarrow \Delta t = \dfrac{\Delta v}{a}.
Therefore,
\Delta t = \dfrac{0 - 20\text{ m/s}}{-9.81\text{ m/s}^2} = 2.04\text{ sec}.
